awd_titl_txt: Group Size, Scaling of Work, and Metabolism in Ant Colonies
awd_abstract_narration:
The pattern of lower energy use per gram with increasing size (known as metabolic scaling) occurs across all animal groups, yet the mechanisms behind it are still not understood. Intriguingly, social insect colonies show the same level of reduced metabolism with increasing colony size. This project will combine experiments and mathematical models to determine the relationships between energy use and the organization of work in ant colonies. Ant colonies serve as an exemplar for this question, because their highly coordinated societies are organized around the work needed to sustain colony growth and maintenance, analogous to metabolic processes in organisms. Understanding the mechanisms underlying metabolic scaling has potential applications in physiology, medicine, and agriculture. The energy-based models and experiments in this project will be relevant well beyond social insect colonies, including informing human population scaling issues. The project will connect this research with a Mathematics and Social Biology Co-mentoring Program, to train research teams of undergraduates together in biology and mathematics. Students will participate in a formal training program on social biological principles and simulation modeling, and then participate as cross-disciplinary teams in collaborative research. Existing connections with research and minority programs at ASU will be used to recruit under-represented students into the program. Teaching modules on group size, social behavior, and metabolism for online K-12 use will also be developed in collaboration with ASU's Ask-a-Biologist outreach program. This project is co-funded by the Animal Behavior program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems, the Mathematical Biology program in the Division of Mathematical Sciences, and the BIOMAPS program for proposals at the interface of Biology, Math and the Physical Sciences.

Group size is one of the most fundamental attributes of sociality, with important effects on social organization and fitness. Previous work has found that larger harvester ant colonies (Pogonomyrmex californicus) exhibit allometric changes in task performance and activity patterns, including increased worker specialization. They additionally shift the allocation of effort, possibly away from more expensive tasks. Potentially coupled with this, colonies also show a consistent pattern of hypometric metabolic scaling, which matches that of organismal scaling patterns. Because task performance is directly linked to colony growth and metabolism, these results lead to the hypothesis that larger colonies achieve economies of scale in energy use from scaling changes in the organization of work. To examine how colony size influences work organization, the distribution of workers across tasks, individual task specialization, and worker activity levels will be measured in laboratory colonies of varying size. Colony metabolism, brood production and growth rates will be measured simultaneously to link behavioral organization to colony metabolic consequences. Additionally, colony demographics, including worker size and age distributions, will be assessed for their contributions to variation in metabolism. These parameters will be measured for: (a) colonies that vary in size but not age; (b) colonies changing in size ontogenetically over time; (c) size-manipulated colonies. The empirical research will be combined with simulation, differential equation and optimization models to ask how components of task organization and activity might interact to generate scaling changes in colony metabolism and productivity.

por.por_cntn:
One of the most universal and puzzling patterns in biology is that larger animals consume and use less energy per gram of body weight. This pattern is extremely important for the function of ecological systems, and is critical to our understanding of animal physiology and energy use. Despite this, the causes of this sublinear relationship remain hotly debated. Recently, we and others have shown that highly coordinated social groups, and in particular social insect colonies, show the same pattern. There are two generalized hypotheses on why energy use is lower at larger size. One is that larger organisms or societies run into resource acquisition and distribution limitations as they gain in size. The other is that smaller organisms or societies must work harder to grow and to compete within a world containing larger individuals. Resolving the mechanisms underlying the energy use scaling question has useful connections to animal physiology and to human societal function as societies become increasingly larger and more interconnected.

Unlike individual organisms or human societies, social insect colonies such as ant colonies can be easily manipulated in size and composition while keeping colony function intact, allowing experimental exploration of the mechanisms underlying changes in energy use with size. Ant colonies in laboratory conditions also can be buffered against resource limitations by the provisioning of resources. Ecological evidence suggests that small social insect colonies face issues of competition that make their survival dependent on successful growth.  We hypothesized, therefore, that small colonies will prioritize those strategies directed to growth, and that this phase in the life of a colony is metabolically more expensive. In turn as they expand, larger colonies may shift investments toward lower-cost activities directed towards maintenance of the physical environment created by larger and denser social groups, and to allow accumulation of reserves to cope with environmental hazards.

We measured the metabolic rates and behavior of harvester ant colonies as they grew from queens to thousands of workers over three years. Small colonies expended more energy per gram than larger colonies, and that increased energy use was directed at production of new offspring. Although brood (developing offspring) themselves had lower metabolic rates, the metabolic costs for the workers increased with the presence of more brood. As colonies grew in size, the proportional number of offspring declined, and the metabolic rate of the colony decreased. The pattern of energy across this period showed an initial phase where metabolism actually scaled higher than linear, and then decreased proportionally to produce an overall scaling pattern that was sublinear. These results strongly support our hypothesis that incipient colonies focus on expensive growth relative to larger colonies, at least partially explaining the decline in energy use per gram in larger colonies. A similar explanation is plausible for the scaling of energy use in animals more generally. Our continuing research supports the behavioral expectation that higher levels of brood production during early colony growth are essential to successfully surviving this period, and that colonies shift allocation of tasks they perform from intense focus on tasks relevant to brood production early on to increasing focus on nest maintenance and social interactions, including social grooming, as colonies grow in size. The research program also used experiments and mathematical models to address questions of information exchange during colony function, how individual variation in task preference and behavior impacts the ability of colonies to respond to changes in colony conditions, and the impacts of task specialization and task switching on costs of work performance.

             As part of this project we also developed and ran a program to train undergraduates in biology and math. The Math-Social Biology Co-Mentoring Program paired undergraduates majoring in biology and applied mathematics to work on research projects, and to attend a seminar and workshops on practical issues of science research. The undergraduate research teams were paired with graduate student mentors, and mentored by faculty in biology and mathematics who led the seminars and workshops. More than 20 undergraduates where supported by this program. This project also partially supported nine graduate students, six of whom have so far obtained Ph.D.’s in math or biology.
